1.7.18  2:02 pm   Sometimes when playing music I'll use string sounds and wind/brass sounds but I play all the parts myself on piano. (I have a pretty decent keyboard and these parts actually sound not too fake). I'd love to one day actually get to play with some horn players or string players. But it's weird writing for instruments you don't play, because I don't know if these parts are playable. I try to stay in their range but there's a whole lot i don't know about the mechanics of these instruments. Like i don't know how long of a phrase a horn/wind player can realistically play without needing space for breathing in between notes/phrases. How fast certain instruments can play or how long they can hold out notes, can this instrument slide up/down to notes and play in between pitches or is it set pitches, stuff like that. I'm worried that I'll spend all this time writing and finally meet musicians to play these parts and they'll be like "dude, that's not possible t o play o n this instrument". I've been on the flip side of this where a piano player has tried to write guitar parts for me, but some of the chord voicings weren't physically possible to play on a guitar. Do you have any experience in this kind of thing, or any advice you can offer? 

     each time you will learn a little bit more

1.7.18  11:58 am   How can I be happy?

     it might be a surprise

1.7.18  11:46 am   Why do song ideas always come to me at the most inconvenient times? When I'm at work, or at the grocery store, or just out in public in general?

     ideas are very playful. that is their way of being playful

      Whenever I can, I try to write the music down or sing it into my phone ASAP. But when I'm at work, I can't just bust out a pad of staff paper and start writing or start singing into my phone.

     yes you can

      Or, if I'm on the train or something I don't want to just be singing into my phone when there's all these other people around me.

     yes you can. you can do it quietly, and professionally

      I really feel like (unless it's something really short and really simple) the idea gets lost (or at least altered) if too much time passes between having the idea and trying to record the idea.

     that is 100% true, that's because it's the first time you've heard it. that's why it's so vitally important to document it immediately

     What do you do when an idea pops into your head and you just for whatever reason can't record/write it out on the spot?

     i have my ways

      Have you stopped caring about people's reactions and will just whip out a phone or voice recorder and sing stuff on the train or at the store or something? 

     there are ways of doing it quietly and professionally, and if i absolutely can't speak, i can document the idea using text alone, and indicate the notes, rhythm, and chords using an elaborate number system. it's tedious and it takes quite a moment, and autocorrect might kick my ass, but it can be done

1.7.18  11:39 am   I think more people would be happier with the answers they got if they went in expecting to get a new perspective on things

     if they didn't want a new perspective then why would they ask a question

1.6.18  5:24 pm   1.5.18  10:30 pm Why is it called that if it has no Eb

     it does have Eb. it is the Eb major chord triad (notes Eb, G, and Bb), except the bass player would play F instead of Eb. they call it Eb over F because it's an Eb chord on top, and F in the bass. in the biz it's written as Eb slash F (Eb/F) at least that's how they do it where i'm from

1.6.18  4:31 pm   Y are triangles so special that they get their own special branch of geometry (trigonometry) and the other shapes dont?

     because they are the first polygon (the least number of sides to have it still be a polygon). the original polygon. you can make any other polygon out of triangles

1.6.18  4:30 pm   Is it ok to ask stupid questions?

     all questions are stupid and smart at the same time. actually everything is stupid and smart at the same time
